I did make a change based around this, but I'm not completely happy
with it=
. I feel like you would want to use the timeout version of the
API; e.g. fo=
r CI servers not to hang waiting for a bad test to
complete. Maybe an annot=
ation or similar could be used to pass an
maxTime value in, otherwise it de=
faults to something reasonable like 2
minutes? Unfortunately, I'm not so fa=
miliar with the 4.x codebase, so
I'm not sure whether that's a good suggest=
ion.

2009/5/1 David Saff <david@...>:
>
>
> Wow. Total code review fa=
il on our part.
>
> Can you log a high-priority bug? We'll smash this bug f=
or 4.7,
> possibly next week's snapshot. If you feel really motivated and a=
re
> skilled in git, feel free to submit a patch. Thanks for keeping us
> h=
onest,
>
> David Saff
>
> On Thu, Apr 30, 2009 at 1:25 PM, mghongslo <mghon=
gslo@...> wrote:
>> I'm reviewing the experimental functionality of r=
unning parallel tests at
>> the class level; i.e. Parallel.classes(), I not=
ice in the ParallelComputer
>> class, run() method there is a call get with=
 a timeout for 2000
>> milliseconds. Is there a significant reason for this=
 versus get() without
>> any timeout? In conducting test without JUnit test=
 cases, I'm finding this
>> timeout feature creates timeout exceptions wher=
eas running JUnit without the
>> timeout allows my test to run successfully=
. Can anyone explain why this
>> timeout is needed?
